awd_titl_txt: Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Scholars Teacher Academy Resident System
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This project at Jackson State University will investigate the effectiveness of a teacher academy resident model to recruit, license, induct, employ, and retain middle school and secondary science and mathematics teachers for high-need schools in the South  It will prepare new, highly-qualified science and mathematics teachers from historically Black universities in high-needs urban and rural schools. The project involves a partnership among three historically Black universities (Jackson, State University, Xavier University of Louisiana, and the University of Arkansas at Pine Buff), and diverse urban and rural school districts in Jackson, Mississippi; New Orleans, Louisiana; and Pine Bluff Arkansas region that serve more than 175,000 students.

Participants will include 150 middle and secondary school teacher residents who will gain clinical mentored experience and develop familiarity with local schools. The 150 teacher residents supported by the program to National Board certification will obtain: state licensure/certification in science teaching, a master?s degree, and initiation. The goal is to increase teacher retention and diversity rates. The research question guiding this focus is: Will training STEM graduates have a significant effect on the quality of K12 instruction, teacher efficacy and satisfaction, STEM teacher retention, and students? science and mathematics achievement? A quasi-experimental design will be used.to evaluate project's effectiveness.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the National Science Foundation through the Discovery Research PreK-12 Program (DR PreK-12) is to catalyze research and develop science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education innovations and approaches that can serve as models for use by the nation?s formal STEM education infrastructure, which includes teachers, schools, districts, and states. 

The Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Scholars Academy Resident System (STEM STARS) project, supported by a grant from the National Science Foundation through the DR PreK-12 program, has created a model that can serve as an example to attract and retain a diverse population of mathematics and science teachers.

The STEM STARS project created a research-driven teacher preparation model to address the shortage of our nation?s science and mathematics teachers. This innovative program was designed to increase the number, quality (certification), and diversity of science and mathematics teachers in high-need school districts in a partnership among Jackson State University, a public urban university in Jackson, Mississippi; Xavier University, a private research university in New Orleans, Louisiana; and University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, a public rural university in Pine Bluff, Arkansas; the Mississippi e-Center at Jackson State University; and high-need school districts in the three-state region. 

The STEM STARS Leadership Team, responsible for the project?s implementation, research, and evaluation, recruited one hundred and twenty (120) prospective teachers in the three-state region. These recruits committed to teach in high-need schools. The Mississippi e-Center supported the project by issuing iPads to prospective teachers and their mentors. 

During the pandemic, all three institutions pivoted from in-person teaching to online teaching with the support of various entities. The STEM STARS project designed and implemented a residency component delivered through the Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) program and modified for STEM STARS. The universities and the leadership team identified alternative points of entry and criteria for students to pursue the MAT.

 

After completing college admissions requirements, the students began Phase I ? Residency Year. They developed skills and acquired the knowledge necessary to become certified science and mathematics teachers. Then they entered Phase II ? Clinical Year, where they participated in ongoing mentoring and professional development activities as they fulfilled their commitment to work in high-need school districts as teachers of record. After the completion of Phase I and Phase II, STEM STARS teachers entered Phase III ? Community of Practice, where

they shared experiences in teaching science and mathematics principles. 

The STEM STARS project?s accomplishments include the following:

  • Produced 120 certified science and mathematics teachers for high-need schools in the Arkansas, Louisiana, and Mississippi three-state region (These teachers could impact approximately 360,000 students during their careers.)
  • Established a partnership among three Historically Black universities and one research center that developed a model to produce more certified science and mathematics teachers in high-need schools/districts
  • Engaged high-need schools/districts to place highly qualified science and mathematics teachers across the three sites
  • Launched a network of science and mathematics teachers and mentors to support teacher retention and student success
  • Provided iPads to teachers and mentors to facilitate the community of practice activities and one-to-one and group mentoring 
  • Developed an innovative strategy for effectively sharing information about the program?s key elements
  • Developed promotional materials, including a What Works document, a film about the STEM STARS program, and numerous other materials (Electronic and print materials on multi-media platforms branded the STEM STARS project.)
  • Created a research-based teacher preparation initiative patterned on the universities? Master of Art programs that can serve as a model for recruiting, preparing, and placing diverse science and mathematics teachers
  • Shared knowledge gained about emerging and best practices with stakeholders, which can make a meaningful difference in the teaching and learning environment

STEM STARS, a research-driven teacher preparation model, increased the number, quality, and diversity of science and mathematics teachers in high-need schools through recruitment, certification (preparation), and placement. The STEM STARS project produced 120 certified mathematics and science teachers in the three-state region who, if they stayed in the profession throughout their careers, would impact 350,000 students.

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2023
Modified by: William E Mchenry
